poem:
Title: The Ordinary's Cinematic Dance

A film, oh mere Drylongso,
Ordinary's but a notion
in hands of sheer creation,
indie razzle of a grad school notion,
Cauleen's reels, blooming with emotion.
20's youth, what distinct infusion,
Embroidered in UCLA's seclusion.
'98 echoes, their dialogue yet not spent,
illuminate the ordinary, with a 25 year lament.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Drylongso review – charming 90s indie is a genre-resistant film that keeps its DIY dazzle The title is an African American term from the US south meaning “ordinary” or “ordinariness” – but there’s nothing ordinary about this 1998 indie from artist and film-maker Cauleen Smith, rereleased for its 25th anniversary. Smith shot it in her 20s while still in grad school at UCLA, and maybe the film does have a distinctive film-school project feel with". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Drylongso review – charming 90s indie is a genre-resistant film that keeps its DIY dazzle The title is an African American term from the US south meaning “ordinary” or “ordinariness” – but there’s nothing ordinary about this 1998 indie from artist and film-maker Cauleen Smith, rereleased for its 25th anniversary. Smith shot it in her 20s while still in grad school at UCLA, and maybe the film does have a distinctive film-school project feel with
